equipment: A clear measured 10-meter (32.8 ft) walkway with marks at 0, 2, 8, and 10 meters.
instructions:
Normal comfortable speed: Have the patient start at the 0-meter mark. Instruct the patient "I will say ready, set, go. When I say go, walk at your normal comfortable speed until I say stop."

Maximum speed trials: Have the patient start at the 0-meter mark. "I will say ready, set, go. When I say go, walk as fast as you safely can until I say stop."

It is suggested to time your patient for a walking distance of 6 m. The time is started when any part of the leading foot crosses the plane of the 2-meter mark. The time is stopped when any part of the leading foot crosses the plane of the 8-meter mark. Document the actual distance timed as 6 m.

If you choose to time your patient for a walking distance of 8 m or 10 m, document the actual distance timed accordingly and start/stop the time when any part of the leading foot crosses the plane of the marks for the correct distance. 

Document the level of assistance required and the type of assistive device and/or bracing used. If a patient requires total assistance or is unable to ambulate, a score of 0 m/s will be documented.

The level of physical assistance is to be documented using the ordinal 7-point scale: 
1 = total assistance [0-24% of task performed]
2 = maximum assistance [25-49% of task performed]
3 = moderate assistance [50-74% of task performed]
4 = minimum assistance [75-99% of task performed]
5 = supervision [required stand-by or set-up assistance; no physical contact provided]
6 = modified independent [assistive device or bracing used, extra time needed, mild safety issues]
7 = independent
mcid_mdc:
MCID = Minimally Clinically Important Difference, MDC = Minimal Detectable Change

Geriatrics: MCID = 0.05 m/s (small meaningful change); MCID = 0.13 m/s (substantial meaningful change).
Parkinson's Disease: MDC = 0.18 m/s (Normal Comfortable Walking); MDC = 0.25 m/s (Maximum Walking Speed).
Spinal Cord Injury: MDC = 0.13 m/s; MCID = 0.06 m/s.
Stroke: MCID = 0.16 m/s; MDC = 0.06 m/s (small meaningful change), MDC = 0.14 m/s (substantial meaningful change).
Traumatic Brain Injury: MDC = 0.05 m/s; MCID = 0.15 m/s (Normal Comfortable Walking), MCID = 0.25 m/s (Maximum Walking Speed).
Hip Fracture: MDC = 0.17 m/s.

These are published values for specific populations and provide guidance if the patient does not have the listed condition.
overview: The 10 Meter Walk Test (TMWT) is a performance measure used to assess walking speed in meters per second over a short distance. It can be employed to determine functional mobility, gait, and vestibular function.
population: The intended population includes the following conditions: Healthy Adults, Traumatic Brain Injury, Cerebral Palsy, Geriatrics, Hip Fracture, Lower Limb Amputation, Movement Disorders, Parkinson's Disease, Spinal Cord Injury, and Stroke.

score_calculation: Two trials should be documented for each speed (normal comfortable speed and maximum speed) to allow an average to be calculated.
score_interpretation:
Stroke: <0.4 m/s more likely to be household ambulators; 0.4 - 0.8 m/s limited community ambulators; >0.8 m/s community ambulators.
Healthy Older Adults: <0.7 m/s indicative of increased risk of adverse events (fall, hospitalization, need for caregiver, fracture, etc.)
